item.name: 1800: Colorado
item.comment: I imagine this was designed as a tool to teach 18xx rather than as a compelling game. I frankly see no space in the genre for it as 1830 can do just as good of a job, if not better, at teaching 18xx to a new player.

One of the most robust financial sandboxes ever created in the board game medium. Given the massive scope of the game, I would imagine that most players will only scratch the surface of all the hidden depths this design has to offer. Only those who truly dedicate the time, energy, and curiosity will tap into its vast toolkit. The game is constantly squeezing players with looming debt and players need to creatively use that toolkit to keep their companies (and themselves) solvent. It's hard to describe just how revelatory it has been to see how different players approach tough situations only to come up with novel solutions to get out of them.
There is only one drawback to a game with the utter totality that 1817 has: length. It is a game that needs time for positions to develop and allow players opportunities to react to each other and the game state. The times I have played 1817 to its defined finish have not been under 6 hours and more often stretched beyond 8. There are several "variants" by other designers that attempted to shorten 1817, but the reality is that they make a huge compromise in strategic depth for a marginally shorter game.
1817 is a special game that only a dedicated few will be able to fully explore. I am sad to say that I cannot be one of them.

item.name: 1822: The Railways of Great Britain
item.comment: Rich incremental cap game. Find the synergies and get to cert limit. Not the type of experience I'm looking for when playing 18xx and I especially am not looking to play this given its length.

item.name: 1830: Railways & Robber Barons
item.comment:
I have been dreading writing this comment because it would mean that 1830 is no longer the perfect game I once thought it was.
The contribution 1830 made to the board game hobby cannot be overstated. It popularized 18xx as a genre and introduced a myriad of novel mechanics for technology progression, stock markets, player-controlled game pacing, map development, and game phases. What’s more, is how utterly fine-tuned the economic structure of 1830 is. A plethora of copy cat games have emerged that borrow 99% of their DNA from 1830 (copying virtually all of its mechanical innovations) yet they all still pale in comparison to the original because they completely miss the underlying economic structure that creates the tension that 1830 does.
However, despite everything 1830 accomplished and the impact it has had, it is not a perfect, 10/10 game. The primary issue 1830 has (to me) is in its pacing. While the game keeps a brisk pace in its first 90 minutes through the yellow and green trains with many interesting decisions actively happening, the following 120 - 180 minutes comparatively become a slog. Don’t get me wrong, the train rush is still a critical part of 1830’s narrative arc, but getting each company a permanent train always takes far longer than I expect it to. And in the event a player doesn’t go bankrupt, we are now staring at 6 to 9 more operating rounds until the $12,000 bank breaks with mostly inconsequential track decisions and static payouts. I feel I make more critical, position-defining decisions in the first hour than I do in the following 3 hours… and when a game like The Old Prince 1871 delivers a consistent stream of critical decision points for the entirety of its 3 hours, I am now reaching for that instead.
I think for a long time I looked past this pacing issue wanting to believe 1830 is right and all other games are wrong, but more recently I have been willing to accept that, despite the impact it had, 1830 is not without its flaws.

item.name: 1841: Railways in Northern Italy
item.comment: With more play, unfortunately this game has started to lose its shine for me. While the game comes with everything but the kitchen sink in terms of chrome, most of it feels inconsequential in the face of the train roster. With how much and how quickly capital can be generated through the corporate ponzi scheme, the game seems to not have time or space for these other mechanics to matter. Players swing big stacks of money at each other and the train roster until one player is left standing. Despite that, navigating the opening auction/floats, the Phase 4 split/merges, and building your capital generating engine is still an incredible experience.

item.name: 1846: The Race for the Midwest
item.comment: A very solid "set 'em up and knock 'em down" 18xx where a large portion of the game happens in the opening draft/initial auction and the rest of the game is seeing it play out. I personally don't feel it plays to the strengths of the 18xx system, but it's also a quick game that manages to pack in a lot of crunchy decisions.

item.name: 1849: The Game of Sicilian Railways
item.comment: While enjoyable for the first dozen or so plays, the "brutal" veil falls off and this game ends up feeling like you are playing 18xx with a hand tied behind your back. The game's scope is limited by having critical tactical moments without providing players tools to appropriately respond. That said, it's quick and is a decent 18xx for 3 players.
Hot potato dressed up as an 18xx game that can drag once players understand that their biggest blunder was sitting down to play 1857.

item.name: 1860: Railways on the Isle of Wight
item.comment: October 2018: Throws out a lot of the traditional ideas and says "Now go have fun kids". Breaks a lot of my 18xx concepts in a very good way. Also, excellent end-game mechanism using nationalization. More 18xx's should use this method for ending the game.

item.name: 1861: The Railways of the Russian Empire
1880: China
item.comment:
Double-O at their best. 18xx games can usually be thought of as a long stock round broken up by operating rounds, but 1880 is a long operating round broken up by stock rounds.
Aside from initial capitalization, the Foreign Investors, and withholding, no money is added to company treasuries. This combined with Communism from Phases 4 to 6 creates a great tension between trying to put cash in hand to pad out your portfolio or to put cash in your company to manage the surprisingly unforgiving train rush. Not to mention the tension of trying to manage the tight cert limit by sacrificing your influence over the map.
A game I bounced off of initially that I learned to appreciate. Lots of fresh ideas and tension in all the right places.

item.name: 18MEX
item.comment: One of the few remixes on 1830 that has something worthwhile to offer. By blunting appreciation on the stock market, tightening up the cert limit, making the 4-trains hard rust on the second 6-train, and introducing a super lucrative train like the 4D, this game shifts 1830 from a stock appreciation game into a revenue-centric one.

item.name: 18OE: On the Rails of the Orient Express
item.comment: I don't think bigger game necessarily means "grander" experience.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment:
Beautiful components. I would play this game for the pretty pictures alone. Incredibly balanced though. Maybe not the first game I would pick for a non-gamer though.
Edit March 2017:
Doesn't scale well with more than 3 players. Not enough control. Typically those who have uncontested military will win.

item.name: 7 Wonders Duel
item.comment: Improves upon the original in virtually every way. Science and military as their own victory conditions, the draft where a player is actively managing what cards their opponent has access to, and a foreign economy to import goods from. This is a solid way to spend 45 minutes if you only have 2 players.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: Merger scrabble that takes 3 hours.

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment: Just a handful of mechanics tightly woven into an even tighter economy. Each player clawing their way to solvency creates all the right kinds of stress and desperation. One of the most (if not the most) elegant game systems to create such an interactive and gut-wrenching decision space. It’s no wonder the system has been used and expanded upon as widely as it has.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
I love creating my farm empire. This game feels less interactive than Puerto Rico, so although I gave them both 10's, Puerto Rico is preferred because your actions more heavily influence others. Of course, I haven't really played with the Interactive deck so I might take everything I just said back soon. A very fun game!
March 2017:
Definitely for folks who wants to manage a lot of things at once. Has a few problems in the options available to players. Would never play this over Caverna.

item.name: The Ancient World
item.comment:
I was drawn in by the worker placement mechanic but the rest of the game completely fell flat. I don't enjoy games where the objectives are cards that come out randomly and if you don't get lucky and see a card you want as a goal, then you can't do much.
I'd like to see the worker placement mechanic reimplemented in another game.

item.name: Android: Netrunner
item.comment: Objectively good game, but I just have no desire to invest the time necessary to discover the depths of the system.

item.name: Antiquity
item.comment:
I've had a lot of ups and downs with this game as I've hated it, then loved it, then thought it was fine but not exactly what I'm looking for.
While Antiquity is indeed interactive around Turn 4 or 5, most of the game leading up to it is not. You are very much solving your efficiency puzzle and making your plans for your victory condition and long-term expansion. Once upon a time I would argue that the game is interactive on Turn 1 because you are anticipating how players would collide on Turn 5, but the reality is that you can have far more interactivity far sooner in other games. Both the city and map puzzles are enjoyable to solve, but they don't really shine with the qualities of what I value in games.

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: Plenty of better party games these days.

item.name: Argent: The Consortium
item.comment:
An anime Hogwarts worker placement game...?
For how bad this game could have been, it was actually not terrible. There was some meat for the worker placement aspects and the scoring mechanism was clever, but when a game is going 2+ hours with lots of important decision-making, it just feels odd to have big "take that!" spells in it. Then again, are you really going to have an anime Hogwarts game without "take that!" spells?

item.name: Arkadia
item.comment:
A tile placing, stock holding game? Neat.
Arkadia puts a fairly unique twist on tile placement as it's less focused on the spatial puzzle and more focused on shared incentives between players. That said, for a "stock" game, the players' ability to control values of each color is just too limited. In my opinion, for a stock game to work, the value of shares needs to be able to shift dynamically and players need to be able to enter or exit positions freely as well. In Arkadia, both of those things happen when a player completes a building and at no other time which leads to prices reacting rather slowly to what's happening in the game. As a result, it's a pretty safe bet to invest into a color others are pumping up themselves and leech off of their hard work. This happened several times in our game when a player would exit with 4 or 5 shares at a value of 4, then immediately after the next 2 players would exit that same color with 4 or 5 shares at a value of 5. I would love to see a more fleshed out version of this tile laying stock game, but as it stands, this game is a bit too clunky to choose when compared to other stock games.

item.name: Arkwright
item.comment: Arguably more of an economic simulator than a game. Not as many tools and gameplay is not as flexible as 18xx even though Arkwright is 2 - 3 hours.

item.name: Automobile
item.comment:
Future market tiles should be in every game.
January 2019: No they shouldn't.

item.name: Azul
item.comment: Surprisingly deep and mean for such a quick teach, setup, and playtime.

item.name: Bausack
item.comment: A game I was enamored with after my first play that fell flat every play thereafter. Every turn (and thus every play) tends to feel the same where you're just trying to give your opponents the most difficult pieces to place.

item.name: Billabong
item.comment:
While I enjoyed my play, I don't expect I'll play this again. Even though it is very rewarding to find double-digit move sequences that bound your roo around the entire map, those moves tend to show up only in the midgame. Early game the roos are still very clustered and late game enough roos have crossed where interesting moves are sparse. The lack of opportunities for big moves in the end leads to lots of incremental (and frankly boring) ones. The game also requiring all 5 of your roos to cross the finish line takes a game that should be 20 minutes and makes it into an hour.
I think it's a cool experience to try to spot a "solution" with the right sequence of moves, but Ricochet Robots just does it better both in terms of implementation as well as time commitment.

item.name: Black Fleet
item.comment: Good for what it is. A silly I steal yours you steal mine pirate game. Good for newer gamers.

item.name: Blood Bowl: Team Manager – The Card Game
item.comment: Not a bad game, but too long for what it is. Should take half the time of what it is.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: Good gateway game. Usually bring it out as an alternative to Settlers.

item.name: Brass: Birmingham
item.comment: This game takes the exemplary qualities of Brass and paints over them with a Euro brush. To me, Brass is about opportunity and interdependence. This game takes focus away from other players over to one's own board. Even though this game is using the Brass system, the times I'd choose to play this game isn't when I'd want to play Brass, but when I'm in the mood for something like Terraforming Mars or Lisboa (which is never).

item.name: Brass: Lancashire
item.comment: While I generally feel that randomness can subvert how meaningful a player's decisions are, Brass perfectly blends tactics and strategy as you need to manage your game plan against the hand you are dealt. Sometimes the cards will not line up with your plan and you will have to pivot into something new. Opportunities will present themselves and you might need to use a card intended for your plan for something else entirely. Players must be constantly adapting to what the game and other players have thrown at them while still building toward their broader goals.

item.name: Brick & Mortar
item.comment:
One thing Brick & Mortar absolutely nails in a way that I've not seen any other game do (not even Food Chain Magnate) is how players can flexibly adjust prices of their goods to either exploit a cornered market or undercut in a competitive one. However, it conducts this through blind bids which is my least favorite auction system as it rewards a player's ability to guess correctly. It is thematic here and the game doesn't really work without blind bids, but this really is a design that took one of my least favorite mechanics and made an entire game out of it.
Another thing worth mentioning is that while the game postures to be mostly about making money by buying and selling goods, it seems a considerable number of points are actually scored through building synergies doing things other than making money. Given the limited pool of available stores (in hand and public stores), it feels like the core economy of the game is undermined by getting randomly dealt/available stores to combo together.

item.name: Broom Service
item.comment: Not a fan of guessing games, even in such a short form as Broom Service. I enjoy predicting what my opponents will do and planning around it, but I do not like how binary the rewards tend to be when the central mechanic of a game is about guessing correctly.

item.name: Bus
item.comment: When a winning score is consistently in the single digits, you know that every opportunity to gain (or take away) a point matters. Bus is short yet desperate and you never quite feel safe until the game is over. While it is a game I do enjoy playing, I often find it more stressful than fun.

item.name: Camel Up
item.comment: Does exactly as advertised. Nice to play after an evening of heavy gaming.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment: Push your luck with dice. It's simple, it's quick, it's fun.

item.name: Cannes: Stars, Scripts and Screens
item.comment: Borrows qualities from Roads & Boats and Bus, but doesn't quite nail the experience of either. The random tile draws are what keeps the game quick, but they are also what holds this game back from being at the same level of other Splotter titles.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 1 – Inns & Cathedrals
item.comment:
With 2 players I'd give it a 7.5. Too random otherwise. Game isn't playable without this expansion.
January 2019: Game isn't playable without this expansion.

item.name: Carson City
item.comment: Played this again after a several year hiatus and I feel I finally experienced Carson City as it was intended to be with lots of tension and dueling. It's still not a game I will reach out for often, but I can see myself agreeing to another 5-player game.

item.name: Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment: The most interesting decision in this game is how to price the buildings. Unfortunately only one player gets to have fun per round.

item.name: Catacombs
item.comment: Great mechanic, but the artwork just felt unfinished. Replacing original artwork with Kwanchai's.

item.name: CATAN
item.comment: The game that got me into games that I have not had the desire to play in 10 years.

item.name: Catch Phrase!
item.comment: A game that is just okay that is played often due to how non-committal it is. No one at a party wants to be locked into a game for even 10 minutes. Players can pop in and out while Theseus' game of Catch Phrase continues on through the night.

item.name: Chicago Express
item.comment: Chicago Express delivers in 45 minutes what most other games cannot deliver in 3 hours. Each track lay or share sold impacts the entire table as the value (and fate) of each railroad drastically changes depending on where the track is laid or who gets the share. Incentives are always shifting and whether you help or hurt a railroad depends on the composition of each player's portfolio. One of the deepest games to come out of such an elegant ruleset and succinct playtime.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: A role selection game that has not stood the test of time. Game takes far too long for what it does.

item.name: Clans
item.comment: Clans creates a wonderful "espionage" experience without any words needing to be exchanged. Resistance or Werewolf largely revolve around shouting accusations, but in Clans, you need to give out some information to achieve your goal, but if you give too much information you expose yourself. Perhaps the only game I've seen to create this dynamic strictly through its mechanics.

item.name: The Climbers
item.comment: While this is a great game for non-gamers, it can sometimes drag as players do everything they can to prolong the game to have a chance at winning.

item.name: Codenames
item.comment: A decent game for large groups since it can accommodate any number of players greater than or equal to 4. The downtime (and pressure) of being the clue giver I feel makes this less of a party game and just a game for large groups though.

item.name: Concordia
item.comment: The definition of elegance and the quintessential mid-weight game. Just a handful of actions and a board to use them on. If this was just a touch more interactive it would see far more play at my table. Unfortunately, this game tends to lose out to Hansa Teutonica when the table is up for a mid-weight Euro.

item.name: Container: 10th Anniversary Jumbo Edition!
item.comment:
An odd one for me. For all the things I value in games, Container should be a resounding 10/10. Yet I generally have no desire to play it and when I do play it, I don't really enjoy it.
You are interacting with other players through purchasing and pricing and bidding, but it's all just so... dry. Most pricing doesn't feel particularly dynamic as prices (in my games at least) tend to cluster around X+1. I have been told this is due to inexperience and that players should be implicitly colluding with their pricing, but if you price high and lock up your goods while others are transacting, you will fall behind (and therefore will eventually drop your prices).
The blind bid is also something I bounce off of. I tend to not like simultaneous action or blind bid systems because, even though it's interesting to anticipate how players will bid, the stakes are just too high for guessing incorrectly. Should I really lose an important lot to another player because I bid just 1 less than them? Does that really mean I'm not playing well by not guessing the exact dollar amount my opponent would bid? It's just such a swingy way to resolve the most important moment in the game as that's how all points are scored. It's a game I want to love, but at this point in time, it's not one I actively look forward to.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment: Party game for 3 - 5 players.

item.name: Coup
item.comment: "I'm the Duke" "I'm the Duke" "I'm the Duke"

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: Flicky and quick. One of the easiest games to get played for 2 - 4 players (I have a board with markings for 3 coming soon).

item.name: Cyclades
item.comment: Instead of being a good dudes on a map game or a good euro game, Cyclades is a mediocre combination of the two.

item.name: Dice Town
item.comment: Great for non-gamers. After I bought this, sooooo many people who never played board games with me got into it. Definitely fun, but lacks some replay value due to its simplicity.

item.name: Discoveries: The Journals of Lewis & Clark
Die Dolmengötter
item.comment: Not about getting an area majority but about swapping area majorities. The movement and blocking mechanisms are neat. While I don't think game has the largest strategic range, it offers some pretty interesting decisions in a quick playtime.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: A classic game that I loved until I didn't. It probably deserves more than a 6 considering how genre-defining it is and how much I enjoyed it in my early days, but I just played it to death and reached a point where the game felt the same despite the millions of possible set combinations.

item.name: Elysium
item.comment: Drafting mechanic was neat, but rest of the game felt tacked on.

item.name: The Estates
item.comment: This game ticks the majority of boxes for what I value in a game. To me, it's about finding what an opponent cares about most and using that against them. There is also a wonderful emergence of alliances as players are locked into their respective rows and realize they need to cooperate. However, one of the highlights of this game is also what holds it back for me. The instability of what will score positively or negatively and lack of control any one player has can make a victory feel coincidental rather than earned. Each game is a fun journey, but I feel great plays by an individual can be overshadowed by cumulative decisions of the table.

item.name: Ethnos
item.comment: El Grande meets Ticket to Ride. I love the idea of attempting to build a specific tribe without committing too much to a hand that may just get dumped back in the pool. However, my plays of this so far have mostly just been sitting around top-decking instead of grabbing discards. Even when Elves and Centaurs are removed, the primary mechanic/tension of the game fails to shine.

item.name: A Fake Artist Goes to New York
item.comment: Spyfall but with drawing. Cute.

item.name: Five Tribes
item.comment: Way too many options on your turn. Great components and idea, but a bit overwhelming to play.

item.name: Food Chain Magnate
item.comment: Once I considered this the best Splotter, but it has fallen out of favor for me. My experience has been that this game is largely about action efficiency and demand control. If a player makes a critical mistake in an early turn that puts them out of reach of key milestones that unlock action efficiency or demand control, they will fall behind with little to no chance to catch up. I don't care for the "catch up" mechanisms in many Euros that arbitrarily punish the leaders, but I also highly value when players in a losing position have flexibility and opportunity to shake up the game state. Splotter famously says "If you can't lose on turn 1, why have a turn 1?" but I would retort "If you don't have a chance to make a come back on turn 2, why have a turn 2?" This is what makes The Great Zimbabwe far and away a better game than Food Chain Magnate as players in a losing position can bring it back in the mid and late game. In Food Chain Magnate the players who are losing just lose more.

item.name: Fresco
item.comment: Simple, easy theme for new players to grab onto, but even at 60 minutes this game is far too long for what it is.

item.name: Fresh Fish
item.comment: The automatic placement is such a clever (and easily goofed!) mechanism. I love how the value of each placement can drastically shift as the board develops. The only thing I'm not a fan of is the blind bidding.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: A game I had to meet on its own terms. Years ago, I was initially frustrated by the lack of decisions and attempted to design a variant where you build the space ships and players fight each other with them (instead of just being hit with random events). I tried it again years later with tempered expectations and realized not all games need to have crunchy, meaningful decisions. Sometimes a game can just be a silly, good time -- and that's exactly what Galaxy Trucker is.

item.name: The Gallerist
item.comment: See Lisboa.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
item.comment: A plodding game of epic proportions. There is plenty to love here for both war game and ASOIAF fans, but for me, the game is far too long for what it is. Each round you are preprogramming actions in each region you are present to either bolster your influence, expand on the map, or defend. You push and pull with your neighbors round to round to set up for your shot at 7 castles/strongholds, but the reality is you are no closer to the game ending at 1 hour than you are at 3 hours. Given that the game end condition is to hit a score of 7 and each house has 1/6 of the total resources at the table, each time a player would vie for the win and get to 6, they would immediately be shut down. This happened to 4 of 6 players. This would likely be addressed with more experience, but the point remains that there is nothing that guarantees progress in the game other than the round tracker. I would really have liked for there to be some way of scoring to mark progress rather than it just being a check when a house hits 7 or at the end of 10 rounds. Perhaps each house has other objectives, perhaps there are other shared objectives, perhaps there are ways to force the game to go only 6 rounds instead of 10, there are lots of options here which I could also see providing options to make gameplay more interesting while also adding more lore.

item.name: German Railways
item.comment: An incredible tongue-in-cheek design. The economy explodes as revenue for each company grows and each share added pays that same revenue without being diluted. Many players get frustrated at the random actions without seeing the game that is happening on the revenue track. I can't help but imagine Bohrer chuckling to himself when he made the actions random, knowing it would infuriate players who are watching the map develop instead of the player payouts.

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment:
Glory to Rome has legends surrounding it due to its publishing status and the unbelievable prices it sells for at auction. Sometimes it's difficult to distinguish fame from game as players will conflate a game's rarity with how good it is. In the case of Glory to Rome though, it really is that good.
While the card draws are from the deck are completely random, the game provides ample tools to mitigate that randomness. There really are only 6 card types so it is likely you will draw into something you can use. Even if you don't immediately draw into what you want, it is easy to cycle your hand. Used cards go to the pool which can then be reused for other actions. And if all else fails, players can use a Jack card. This is one of the few examples of a card game that I feel gives players enough control and agency to control their own fate.
In terms of how it plays, to me, Glory to Rome is a race to see who can break the game first. Once a player gets their combo online, it snowballs and they are favored to win. This makes managing early actions, resources, and opportunities incredibly important. But it usually only takes 30 - 45 minutes for a winner to emerge and it is easy to play a second, third, fourth, etc round after.

item.name: El Grande
item.comment: Sometimes it is true what they say -- El Grande just does it better. There isn't an ounce of fat on this game and tension throughout. I am constantly balancing my own cards/court against what is happening on the board and what action cards have come up this round. There are plenty of great area control games, but El Grande is just so engrossing for its entire 90 minutes that I expect I would prefer to play it over any games that have attempted to improve upon it.

item.name: El Grande: König & Intrigant
item.comment: A "better" game that is actually worse. This game eliminates luck by letting each player build a hand of 13 (out of 18) action cards at the beginning of the game. For me though, this variant took away the soul of the game while making it far more chaotic and less predictable. In the original, each round a set of 5 possible actions are presented to you and the players must think through what each other wants. In this expansion, on the first round there are something like a million possible things that can happen (18*17*16*15*14). It takes what is essentially an auction for 5 items and makes it a guessing game about 50 items and ultimately subverts the soul of El Grande.

item.name: Great Western Trail
item.comment: For how many mechanisms are in here, Pfister got them to gel pretty well. Wish there was more interaction between player buildings as I feel each player ends up building their own rondel rather than interacting with each other's paths. Still though, it's nice to occasionally mosey down the trail to ship some cattle.

item.name: The Great Zimbabwe
item.comment:
At first glance, the VR mechanism in The Great Zimbabwe is a clever twist on how a winner is determined. Instead of seeing who scored the most, each player is racing to their own finish line. However, the underlying value of this mechanism is that it distills time into its own currency and offers players a flexible way to borrow from the future.
Many games have an economic snowball of compounding wealth/points or abilities locked behind prerequisites of careful planning. Those who are already ahead get further ahead while those who are behind fall further behind. In Zimbabwe, if a player recognizes they are losing, in a single turn they can take on VR to pivot their position to shake up the game state and turn their position into a winning one.
Despite checking all the boxes for what I look for in games, this flexibility is what separates Zimbabwe from other short shared-incentive games and is why it keeps hitting the table for me after nearly 70 plays.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica
item.comment: An elegant game that is incredibly easy to get played due to its minimal setup, low rules overhead, and quick playtime. Immediately players are getting in each other's way demanding their cube tax and the Hansa Teutonica standoff begins. Perhaps my one complaint about this game is you get rewarded for building your engine and your route. I would like to see a player win from focusing on their route and office points only, but I tend to see the player who focused on their engine and then their route win.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment: A design certainly worth appreciating even though I don't particularly seek out playing it. Rather than have the players build their own engines, the game's engine comes online on its own in a predetermined sequence. The primary value of owning a building is not a passive income but reserving the right to use that building in a critical moment. A very neat game of tempo and blocking.

item.name: Here I Stand
item.comment:
6 factions, each with their own script that a player needs to execute against. There is wiggle room within those scripts to capitalize on opportunities, but if you stray too far, you waste resources and set yourself back.
Game is dripping with theme and history which I like. A very "epic" experience. But for a game that takes 8 hours, I need more decisions than "Send out an explorer, build a chateau, convert some cities to Protestant, roll some dice and pray"

item.name: Hinkel & Stein
item.comment: My first game was a blast (with plenty of hooting and shouting) but the gimmick loses its novelty fairly quickly. With only 4 powers, there isn't much to explore here.

item.name: Homesteaders
item.comment: One broken strategy. Very linear gameplay after first game.

item.name: Imhotep
item.comment: A fine game, but perhaps not enjoyable enough to see much play.

item.name: Indonesia
item.comment:
Despite being nearly 20 years old, no game executes mergers as elegantly as Indonesia. Most games that I’ve seen use mergers require the owners of the merging entities to agree to the merger, which usually ends up with one player merging their own things together rather than merging with other players. Indonesia on the other hand, allows for Player A to call a merger between Player B and Player C and Player D could be the one who wins it. It’s a pretty simple merger system, but the result is dynamic gameplay where players are actively pivoting in and out of different positions throughout the game.
The flexibility to react to the game state and change your position is the central pillar of what I value in games. What Indonesia offers beyond that though, is the ability to take another player’s position for your own. If a player is making a killing on rubber and you’re just selling rice, you can merge your rice company away which gives you enough cash to call and win a merger on the rubber company. I find it to be fairly rare for players to be able to bid what a company is worth, so Indonesia (to me) is largely about finding those opportunities to have the most bidding power when those critical mergers are called (and sometimes that can just mean locking up other players’ slots).
A last point to make is that even though the map and company starting regions do not change, the way the map builds out is incredibly different game to game which has a significant impact on shipping mergers, player revenues, city growth, and company expansion. First time players tend to be more collaborative with clusters of cities and shipping in the south. Even on a second or third play, the cities and shipping start to spread out as shipping players realize they are being out-earned.
The one thing that falls a bit flat for me is the turn order bid. Perhaps this is just my group, but bids tend to just be one more than that previous bid or 0. I get that you are trying to maneuver turn order to go last one round so you can guarantee first in a later round, I just don't know if a once-around auction is my preferred way to handle that. That said, it is a very minor issue in the face of what the game accomplishes.

item.name: Inis
item.comment:
A game I always think I'll enjoy more than I do. One thing I adore about this game is how you aren't fighting large battles but mostly small skirmishes between a handful of units. The fact that a win condition isn't based on beating your opponent but being chief over as many of your opponents' pieces as possible means you want your opponent to lose units, but only just enough. I feel this is a great solution as many games with conflicts end up with each player amassing an army to engage in only one or two conflicts for the entire game. In Inis, every round clashes are happening and the board is shifting.
Actions are controlled by a limited set of cards which gives each round a rhythm and predictability as players anticipate the cards that haven't been seen yet this round. The multiple win conditions keeps players options open to shift to new opportunities as others close. And yet... and yet... the game still suffers from enough issues that I can't love it despite all these wonderful things it has going for it.
Perhaps the largest issue is the "blue shell" problem where if you're in first place, players will expend every last resource to prevent your win. Once the leader has been taken down, the player who held onto cards and hid how close they were to winning plays a green action card and casually saunters across the finish line. This has happened in virtually every game of Inis I've played. It is not about making a clever play that is so creative that there is no rebuttal, it is about being the last person to play cards when your opponents have exhausted their ability to react. This means that passing (i.e. abstaining from play) is your best action which to me feels degenerate.
Not to mention that while the game advertises itself as a 45 - 60 minute experience, for me it seldom goes below 90. Some of this is a result of AP, having to learn so many cards and the fact that every round begins with a draft, however I'd say a bigger factor is that players have so much influence over the board state. It is difficult for one player to make a play that lands them a decisive win. Players will often be grabbing pretender tokens for 1, 2, or even 3 rounds before a winner emerges. These final rounds also take far longer than one would expect as the board state becomes noisier and the game of "passing chicken" begins.

item.name: Irish Gauge
item.comment: Almost too light and restrictive to choose this over Chicago Express, but hey it's 30 minutes.

item.name: Istanbul
item.comment: While the board setup has variability the gameplay does not.

item.name: Jamaica
item.comment: There are better gateway games than this.

item.name: John Company
item.comment: I desperately tried to like this game but every experience was just short of random with the dice checks and event cards. For it to work as a narrative game, you need the right player count, with the right personalities, with the right experience which didn't line up often for me. I love what the design attempts to do and its tongue-in-cheek commentary, but as a game it lacks the meaningful decisions that would justify its playtime.

item.name: Kanban: Driver's Edition
item.comment: Perhaps the best of the Lacerda games. While it suffers from the same issue as his other games (way too much overhead and rules complexity for the decision space the game offers) the sequencing of Kanban's action selection system is what sets it apart. Whenever you move your worker, several actions are guaranteed to be blocked, but it is not a matter of what is blocked but when it is blocked. One of the few games I've seen be carried by a single mechanic.

item.name: Kemet
item.comment: Great everything. Only probably is the one broken tech tree. Fixed with house rules though.

item.name: Keyflower
item.comment: While I still consider this game to be highly interactive and one of the best worker placement games to date, it is no longer interactive enough for my tastes. Winter still has incredible tension and I love how players need to earn their right to score, but once the players' engines are online, the game shifts to be about exploiting those engines. Players can throw a wrench in each other's plans and outbid on critical scoring tiles, but that ends up being secondary to extract out every last point with the limited meeples and action tiles.

item.name: KLASK
item.comment: If air hockey were a board game.

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
Libertalia
item.comment: The role selection is effectively a blind bid auction which rewards you for guessing what other players would pick correctly. I enjoy trying to predict what my opponents will do, but I'd prefer that not to be the core game mechanic.

item.name: Lignum
item.comment: I wanted to love Tokaido: Extreme Edition. Balancing all the resources, timing, and your opponents racing around the track presents a crunchy puzzle. However, I feel recipe fulfillment is a very uninspired way for players to earn their win and ultimately undermines the redeeming qualities of the game.

item.name: Lisboa
item.comment:
My main issue with this Lacerda game is the issue that I have with all Lacerda games: the amount of systems and complexity and rules overhead do not justify the decision space they provide.
As an example, in Puerto Rico when I take the build action, each player has an opportunity to buy a building. With one player's action the entire table gets to build. In Lisboa, to build a public building, you must first get a plan, then get State Officials, and then take the build action. Most actions have 2 or 3 step workflows each with their own mechanisms to track and each turn you chip away at them. It feels more like project management than decision making.

item.name: Locomotive Werks
item.comment: If the train rusting mechanic from 18xx were its own game. Sometimes you get screwed by the dice, but the game is short and it can actually teach important lessons to become a better 18xx player.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
item.comment: Shorter Stratego with unique character powers. Not a bad way to kill 20 minutes with 2 players.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment: Simple recipe fulfillment game. I most likely won't agree to a game of it these days, but it has its place in many collections.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: A bit too simple for my taste.

item.name: Die Macher
item.comment: A groundbreaking game that has not stood the test of time. Board games have evolved in the 40 years since Die Macher arrived and more interesting decision spaces can be delivered in far less time.

item.name: Machi Koro
item.comment: Only playable with Harbor expansion, but even then, not fantastic.

item.name: Medici
item.comment: If this game was innovative in 1995, it sure isn't today. Frankly, a once-around auction where the auctioneer (who made the lot) has final say is boring. It creates situations where the auctioneer is trying to create lots they want rather than lots other players want. I much prefer something like The Estates where you are trying to start auctions to target your opponents' vulnerabilities. Also, the lot creation is often described as "push your luck", but the reality is you are only deciding if a 2nd or 3rd tile will be drawn. It is just not very dynamic and can be incredibly swingy. There are enough decent auction games that I don't need to play Medici again.

item.name: Medina (Second Edition)
item.comment: Lots to love here as the game has elements of spatial planning and push-your-luck. Since you are forced to play pieces on your turn, you want ensure those pieces are for your benefit and not an opponent. Do you take the guaranteed 8-point orange structure now? Or will that mean all the orange blocks you still have in hand is going to build a 12-point structure for someone else? I didn't particularly care for how the wall points were claimed as it felt like a game of chicken in the end where you just want to be the last player with pieces.

item.name: The Mind
item.comment: Wolfgang Warsch is making a career out of making quirky games that can appeal to both gamers and non-gamers. A minute to teach and 10 minutes to play, this game has ended up being a surprisingly good palate cleanser and gateway game.

item.name: Modern Art
item.comment:
Sorry to do it to you, Doc. As my gaming tastes evolve, I've found that gameplay that revolves solely around auctions and nothing else don't feel dynamic enough to me (and a bit dry).
The core tension in Modern Art is trying to value items that are not guaranteed to score. In my experience though, any players who have already committed to a color are incentivized to ensure that color will score. This leads to others being incentivized to auction off colors that are already present on the board because, since they are more likely to score, they are more likely to be auctioned for a higher value. The 2x cards also force the issue because they immediately get a color to jump out ahead. A lot of it does seem to come down to luck based on what you were dealt and where you sit relative to the current auctioneer (perhaps the auctioneer is sitting immediately to your right and puts up a blue card while you have a 2x and another blue in hand, you can get a great deal on it and set up blue to be very likely to score).

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: A 4X game with a decent battle system that you can play in 60 minutes? This is a solid game that just doesn't happen to align with my gaming preferences these days.

item.name: The Old Prince 1871
item.comment:
Part of what makes this such a good game is just how awkward it feels. In many 18xx games, players have a pile of cash and start with fairly differentiated positions right out of the gate. However, in The Old Prince, the initial auction tangles all the positions together into the Mainline, Shortline, and PEIR. It is very uncomfortable and a player’s first reaction might be to break away from these positions as quickly as possible… but with their cash tied up and tranches that limit the number of companies that can start, it is challenging for players to find their exit (and therefore must tolerate the awkwardness).
As the game progresses, players eventually negotiate their way out of the starting positions and the PEIR is the vehicle used to conduct that negotiation. The PEIR develops track for all the unstarted companies and dangles carrots in front of players of what they should float. Since floating a new company will convert a PEIR share and a PEIR token over to the floated company, there are huge implications about who will operate the PEIR and where the PEIR can run its trains. Sometimes you might float a company because you want to take an excellent route away from the PEIR. Other times, you float the company with no route just so you can wrest control of the PEIR. Sometimes you split off of another company rather than floating a PEIR company so players with PEIR shares are stuck holding them (often with the PEIR having no routes or trains).
And all of this disentanglement is happening while the train clock is ticking. The train roster is long and trains rust relatively quickly, but if players aren’t keeping the game moving by buying trains, the Union Bank starts to capitalize and bank player easily wins with a share lead.
As I approach 80 plays of this title, I am still learning new things with each play like what makes Mainline different from Shortline, why/when you should split, when there will be a train stall between tranches, even thinking of different Mainline builds for each of the companies. There is far more going on beneath the hood than most players will realize. Very excited to keep digging into this one.

item.name: Panamax
item.comment: Played again recently and remembered why I disliked the game in the first place. The contracts dictate a lot of what you can do. With only 3 contracts out on display, contracts in countries you don't want to load, and die values on the contracts that don't work for you, you're basically trying to make the best of what the game throws at you. You aren't really playing the game, the game is playing you.

item.name: Patchwork
item.comment: A game that does what is advertised. A quick 2-player game with a handful of crunchy decisions. If I did more 2-player gaming this would probably see more play.

item.name: Pax Pamir: Second Edition
item.comment:
There is so much to love about Cole Wehrle's approach to game design both in terms of his dedication to iterative design as well as his deep integration of history. I often feel he is trying to communicate an underrepresented point of view rather than just make a game.
However, I feel that board games as a medium should primarily be used to create a competitive space and tell such narratives through its mechanics. Pax Pamir teases a world of possibility with all of its espionage, taxation, conflict, and fluid allegiances, but the reality is you are handcuffed to a handful of tactical reactions based on card conveyor belts. Each action in each region is tied to specific cards with additional actions attached to those cards. Given that you will most often just have a few rupees, the cards available to you are just in the 2 or 3 leftmost columns. Occasionally you will spend more than 3 rupees for a card, but unless it's a dominance check, you are likely overpaying, losing tempo, and will wish you had saved those rupees for said dominance check.
Players end up reacting not to each other but to how the deck was stacked at the start of the game. This isn't to say that there is no agency and no decisions, just that the decisions are highly tactical. Each turn is about finding the immediately optimal move given the limited predictability for what the board will look like 2 turns from now. Unfortunately, I don't feel this game has strategic depth that is commensurate with its rich history and setting.

item.name: Perudo
item.comment: A jolly push-your-luck game that's an easy teach. I played it more in my early gaming days, but will still break it out occasionally.

item.name: Piratenbillard
item.comment: A very unique dexterity game that is as fun as it is frustrating to play.

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment: Crokinole but cars. Three laps feels like it might be a touch too long, but that's probably because I'm terrible.

item.name: Planet Steam
item.comment:
Power/turn order auction, territory claiming, resource production, dynamic markets, with modular minis in a steampunk setting??? This game has it all!!
...and sadly none of that makes it a game worth playing.
Rather than isolating one or two mechanics to do well, Planet Steam added every possible mechanic and all were mediocre. None of the mechanics seem to gel that well together and each has its own set of quirks. The market is where the meat of the game is, but a lot of the buying or selling with a particular good seems to have a lingering impact on the price for several rounds. Like a ghost of our previous actions is still haunting the price. With the plethora of great economic and strategy games out there, there isn't much reason for this one to be in your collection or on your table.

item.name: Polynesia
item.comment: Personally, the 2 types of currencies (shells and fish) felt a bit clunky to me. The game is fairly simple, but there is surprisingly more overhead than needed when it comes to network development or movement.

item.name: Ponzi Scheme
item.comment: A game where one player is guaranteed to bankrupt the moment it starts. The very nature of the game is degenerate and it kind of doesn't work, but if you just ignore the fact that the best way to win the game is by playing less than your opponents, the game is jolly.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: A good game that usually is just not good enough to see play. Even ignoring the issues I have issues with the power plant auction, most of the map and turn order tension is better-handled in Age of Steam. Given the similar game length, Age of Steam will typically be picked.

item.name: Project L
item.comment: Cute for a first play, but wears out its welcome fairly quickly.

item.name: Pueblo
item.comment:
A game that fully utilizes its 3D space. Perfect information and players have lots of influence how the chieftain moves and therefore how it will score for each player. The one unfortunate aspect of this game is that, given how much control players have, it is very easy to bash the leader. No amount of clever placement can combat all other players working against you.
Clans has a great mechanism to hide what color each player will score. This means that even though players have a lot of influence over each other, it comes with risk and prediction about how each other player will behave. I'm not sure a mechanic like that would quite fit in a game like Pueblo, but it would be neat if it could.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: A great game that didn't age as well as other classics from a similar time. It still amazes me how drastically different scores could be despite players taking the same actions. However, I have not played this game or felt the desire to play this game in years.

item.name: The Quacks of Quedlinburg
item.comment: For all of the things I value in games, Quacks checks very few of those boxes. However, Quacks is silly game that knows it's silly and does not overstay its welcome. Even though it's a multi-player solitaire push-your-luck game, the simultaneous action keeps turns quick and the game lasts just long enough for you to build your engine and not a turn longer. I am perfectly happy ending an evening of 18xx with a game of Quacks.

item.name: Quantum
item.comment: Swingy dice rolling fun with a clever mechanism for both a ship's movement and type to be based on its die value. Definitely not the deepest title, but at 30 minutes it does its thing and gets off the table which I like.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: Don't make me test your game for you.

item.name: The Quest for El Dorado
item.comment: Quick and jolly. I sometimes feel the game ends before I can get a real engine online, but I think keeping the game short is probably more important than depth for this one.

item.name: Quo Vadis?
item.comment: While I'm not usually a fan of negotiation games, I am a big fan of Quo Vadis. The incentives and how much each negotiation is worth are always so clear. There is a great balance between players needing to negotiate and when players can act independently. There is no negotiation game I'd rather play than this.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: To think of how many gaming sessions Ra hasn't been a part of all these years is just saddening. To me, Ra is an incredible blend of luck, tactics, and strategy. The values of the lots are so immediately dynamic and differentiated between players. The bidding tiles are brilliant as it creates enough constraint on what players can bid that you can plan around how they will use them. Ra addresses virtually every issue I had with Medici and I see no reason to ever play Medici again as I will just wish I was playing Ra.

item.name: Rail Pass
item.comment: A game I was excited to love but the difficulty felt mostly arbitrary. I've only played at high player counts 5 and 6 (which is the group size I would prefer for a game like this) and it was too easy. We reduced the time and it was still too easy. Arguably we could keep calibrating the time to get to a point where we felt the game was sufficiently difficult, but at the point we're not proving anything.

item.name: Railroad Ink: Blazing Red Edition
item.comment: It takes 10 minutes to play and has some interesting tension points, but, like most roll and writes, this isn't a board game but a multi-player puzzle.

item.name: Reef
item.comment: Still deciding if I like this one. While it's marketed as a gateway game, it can actually be quite challenging to play well. I just find that Azul has me focusing more on what all players are doing while Reef has be staring at my own board, so I tend to reach for Azul.

item.name: Res Arcana
item.comment: A lean game where you're trying to squeeze the potential out of the limited resources you have access to. Looking forward to trying this one more.

item.name: The Rich and the Good
item.comment:
"The best Knizia game that was not designed by Knizia." -Mudville9
Stock markets need uncertainty to function. While most games use random events to create uncertainty, Hab & Gut provides all information to its players... the only catch is that each player only has access to a portion of that information which overlaps with their neighbors. This creates a very interesting space for players to plan and predict their moves based on how their neighbors are behaving. Sometimes imbalanced situations can occur when a stock gets super cheap and it sells out before some players have a chance to purchase it, but at least the price of those shares was driven by the players and not random events.

item.name: Ricochet Robots
item.comment: A thinky party game? While I'm sure most would bounce off of this game, it's quick, can adapt to any player count, and is non-committal (you can walk away from the table at any time without disrupting the game). Every time I fail to see a solution I am just taunted by the game to keep playing to figure out the next one. Perhaps one of the greatest thinky fillers out there.

item.name: Roads & Boats
item.comment: Cute but fiddly. Most of the scenarios I've played have a lot of space between players to start, so my experiences have mostly felt like multi-player solitaire until the final rounds. I would like to try a more compact map to see the interactive side of Roads & Boats. Even then however, I don't really find movement planning to be an interesting decision space and don't expect my feelings about R&B to drastically change.

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment: Random. Which is what it's meant to be, but just can't get into it.

item.name: Rolling Stock
item.comment:
A truly novel financial system that almost borders on being a simulation. I generally prefer the online implementation to the physical game since there can be a lot of arithmetic and upkeep (which apparently is streamlined in Rolling Stock Stars).
For as fantastic as the system is, my main hangup with it is that unless you are actively making deals with other players to swap around companies, players will one by one miss "the wave" and effectively be eliminated from the game. I'm not a huge fan of negotiation in Rolling Stock as I feel one player will always get the worse end of the deal but they are kind of forced to take it. I don't feel that a losing player is improving their chance of winning in a negotiation, just delaying the inevitable. That's just been my experience though.

item.name: The Ruhr: A Story of Coal Trade
item.comment: More things to manage does not mean more interesting to play.

item.name: Rummikub
item.comment: Good for those who like Rummikub. I think it's kind of like Chess; those who play it get really, really good and primarily that only that game. I own it, but the person who requested I buy it moved. Upon her return I'll probably get more into it.

item.name: San Marco
item.comment: It's hard to make area control work at 3 players but San Marco does a decent job of it. It is also perhaps one of the best implementations of "I split, you choose" that I've seen. However, one of the inherent issues I have with ISYC is that it often ends up with analysis paralysis. One player is trying to make 3 lots that are roughly the same value (or at least equally valued to the player making the lots). This means that player is trying to analyze the board state, each player's position, and what the impact of each lot is... and this mental exercise is happening every single turn. It almost feels like the game isn't played simultaneously, but rather each player is taking their turn to play the game. San Marco does what it was designed to do quite well, I just don't know if ISYC is my preferred way to distribute actions/resources.

item.name: Santiago
item.comment: I can appreciate that a lot of the gameplay revolves around who the canal overseer is and planning your bids, placements, and bribes around that player's incentives, but that's also what holds this game back for me. You are mostly concerned about planning around 1 player's incentives each round for 9 rounds. I would just rather play a game where I'm actively considering what each player wants on every single turn.

item.name: SCOUT
item.comment: A great climbing game. The ability to scout the current hand to weaken it for the next player (while also awarding points to whoever played that hand) is a brilliant mechanism. It creates enough tension where players are trying to balance taking on more cards to play a big hand or trying to get cards out as quickly as possible.

item.name: Scythe
item.comment: Why put mechs in the game if I can't do mech things with them.

item.name: Sheriff of Nottingham
item.comment: Everyone tells me I should be having fun playing this but I still have yet to enjoy.

item.name: Shikoku 1889
item.comment: https://medium.com/grandtrunkgames/why-shikoku-1889-quick-to-learn-a-lifetime-to-master-882df8673d97

item.name: Shipyard
item.comment: I'd rather have one interesting rondel than twelve uninteresting ones.

item.name: Skull
item.comment: Liar's Dice but with coasters. I think Liar's Dice is a more enjoyable game, but Skull does have multiple win conditions and plays in 10 minutes. Skull has its place at a table of non-gamers, but not really anywhere else.

item.name: Slapshot
item.comment: I have Kwanchai's version and that's probably the main reason I enjoy it. The characters make me feel like I'm playing a Super Smash Bros card game. A little simple for me, but Kwanchai's redesign made it worth playing.

item.name: Small World
item.comment: The game everyone loved until they didn't. Had my fun with Small World but eventually needed more interesting decisions.

item.name: Stephenson's Rocket
item.comment: A very novel take on "cube rails" games that predates the entire cube rail genre. Very interested to explore this one.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis!
item.comment: A good way to make enemies. Also a good beginner game. The components of the recent reprint are fantastic.

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment: I thought the game of chicken bidding system would be interesting, but it didn't feel particularly dynamic to me.

item.name: Taluva
item.comment: With 30 minutes and 4 players, there aren't many games I would pick over Taluva. It packs a lot of really tough decisions into a short playtime despite its light ruleset. Most games are very tight with each player in striking distance of victory and I find there are always opportunities players can pivot into.

item.name: Terra Mystica
item.comment: I would compare playing Terra Mystica to wringing out a wet towel; every turn you are trying to do a lot with a little and you are just trying to squeeze out every possible action you can. I do have a few gripes about game length, the cult track, and the round scoring/bonuses, but for how much the game has going on it all gels very well in a fairly interactive and perfect information space (which is a feat for any game to accomplish).

item.name: Terra Nova
item.comment: Lots of information to parse initially, but a very cool game about managing zones and how they score. The scoring uses inverse multiplicity which creates an interesting tension between going for small zones of one terrain type or large zones of multiple terrain types (and hopefully an area majority).

item.name: Terraforming Mars
item.comment:
I can see why Terraforming Mars has been so popular for the past 6 years. It's a great feeling to build an engine with a plethora of synergies all working together. It's just not the primary thing I look for in a game.
I find it interesting that people consider 18xx to be harder to play than Terraforming Mars. Every time I sit down to play TfM, I am inundated with all kinds of cards with various effects, costs, text, etc. and trying to pick the 1 out of these 10 cards that I want is more overwhelming than most 18xx titles I've played.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment: Controlled chance. Not terrible.

item.name: Three Kingdoms Redux
item.comment:
I want to love this game. Fantastic flavor, history, theme, etc. Amazing idea to have a 3-player asymmetrical game.
But it just takes so long for what boils down to be a worker placement auction. If I could play this in 90 minutes, I'd really love this game. My first and second play sessions went 5 hours and 4 hours respectively. When you get into that time window, something else is hitting the table. Yes, the players had AP issues (myself included) but that's driven by each worker having multiple unique traits and an ability. Even with more experience, I don't see this game falling below a 2 hour play time.

item.name: Through the Ages: A New Story of Civilization
item.comment: A board game that has been entirely replaced by the app for me. While I do feel playing the game well does require knowledge of virtually all of the cards, once you do know them there is a lot of room for creativity in how you get your win.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment: This would be an acceptable alternative to Ticket to Ride except for the fact that Ticket to Ride is a 1 minute teach while this is a 5 minute teach. That marginal increase in complexity creates a surprising amount of overhead for new players to learn and remember and thus Thurn & Taxis is seldom picked.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: One of the fastest teaches and also one of the fastest games for players to start making clever plays after learning. That instant payoff for such a simple teach is what I think has kept Ticket to Ride on tables despite being nearly 2 decades old. Despite that, I have played enough Ticket to Ride and can't think of the last time I sought it out.

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment:
One of the classics that has stood the test of time and lived up to its reputation. The board is a tinder keg with a series of chain reactions waiting to go off -- chain reactions that will vary greatly depending on which players are placing which tiles in which locations.
In many other games, when something is placed on the board it is permanent. However, in Tigris & Euphrates, external conflicts pull tiles off the board which can fragment large kingdoms into smaller kingdoms and regions. To me, this is the defining feature of the game because it creates opportunities for leaders to swoop in and for new kingdoms to form; not to mention how it creates noise for how the board and relative positions will change between turns. Kingdoms rise and fall while being touched by each player in some way and the narrative arc of these civilizations is not told but shown.

item.name: Tokyo Highway
item.comment: A nice filler. My main gripe is that if a player knocks a piece over, they need to put it back the way it was. This can slow the game down quite a bit as the player who knocked something down in the first place might not be the most adroit player to begin with. (leading to even more pieces knocked over and more waiting for highway repairs)

item.name: Trajan
item.comment: Another Stefan Feld "gimmick game". Not enough interaction. You spend most of your time trying to just figure out your mancala you don't think about much else. I've enjoyed playing though.

item.name: Tricktakers
item.comment: Tricktaking but with pickable characters who have different powers and objectives each round. The characters give each round an interesting twist as that actively changes how strong each player's hand is as well as how often they are trying to win. That said, what holds this game back for me is just how small the hands are each round. When you are playing out a 5 card hand, I felt that my hand was more playing itself than I was playing it. While the powers add some choices, players didn't seem to have enough control over their hands to make it as meaningful as I would have liked -- particularly when a game like SCOUT! offers lots of decisions for hand management with a similar playtime.

item.name: Vegas Showdown
item.comment:
So fun! I like building up my empire in front of me. The first 3 times I played this game, I played incorrectly thinking that you collect income before each individual person makes a bid, therefore, I hated it because everyone had too much cash and there was no point to bidding. Once I figured out what we were doing wrong, this has become top 5.
March 2017:
Good game, but solved. Bidding mechanic should be used in more games. Probably best bidding mechanic I've seen.

item.name: Wavelength
item.comment: My first 3 plays of Wavelength were amazing. My next 3 plays of Wavelength were boring. Each clue plays out the same way with some initial guesses and a discussion to calibrate it. Enjoyable at first, but the novelty wore off quickly.

item.name: Welcome To...
item.comment: While I avoid multi-player solitaire games, I thought this would be an interesting and quick gateway game. Instead, it was neither of those things.

item.name: Wildcatters
item.comment: Some interesting interdependence and shared incentives, but ultimately could not depose the other titans that fill this slot in my collection.

item.name: Wits & Wagers
item.comment: A party game with some strategy. I prefer it for large groups and to play in teams. More than 10 is ideal.

item.name: Wiz-War
item.comment:
I have Kwanchai's redesign. I don't know how I feel about this yet, it may go up the list, but for the few times I've played it, I got frustrated that I could only act based upon the cards drawn. Many times I didn't have a decent spell to cast. Maybe if the cards were separated into specific piles? I can see that this game has a lot of depth that I've yet to tap, so currently it's an 8, but I could easily see it becoming a 9.
March 2017:
It is exactly what it set out to be. A silly game. Enjoyable if that's what you're looking for.

item.name: Zendo
item.comment: A favorite "nightcap" to close out an evening of gaming. Rounds are quick and non-committal as one-by-one players head home for the evening while the game continues. To me, Zendo is the physical manifestation of a riddle which has made it a hit with both gamers and non-gamers alike.

item.name: Zombie Plague
item.comment:
Kwanchai's redesign again. Awesome to play after watching a zombie movie. I get frustrated when I get the pie as a weapon, but I appreciate the humor in the game. Lots of cards meaning lots of variations between plays. Always fun to play in the dead of night.
March 2017:
Not a fan of coops but if that's what the mood of the group asks for, I'll play it.

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment: Good to pull newer gamers off Settlers and offer a different, yet light experience.
